body:
You shouldn't need to mock a pipeline provider, as you could just create an empty one with nothing configured and build it, which will give you a no-op strategy that does nothing other than invoke the delegate you wrap with it.

Keyed services isn't mentioned in our documentation because we just didn't look into it as we were busy getting Polly v8 ready for .NET 8 itself to make use of.

If you'd like to contribute an example to our documentation suggesting how one could use keyed services to configure Polly resilience strategies, that would be interesting.

Ah, sorry, I was thinking of a pipeline itself, which would be done thusly:

```csharp
ResiliencePipeline pipeline = new ResiliencePipelineBuilder().Build();
```

If your constructor took a named pipeline, then you could just directly inject an empty pipeline to it without any reference to a pipeline provider at all.

Yes they are the same, I just forgot the property existed.

Personally I'm not keen on adding this mock/substitute in-box as it isn't so simple as an empty pipeline because it has parameters to provide different names, so there's many ways people might want it to behave and then it's a slippery slope of "what about one that behaves this way?".

This is trivial to implement as a mock in your tests and you can factor it for re-use in your tests to reduce duplication.

Thanks, @martintmk, that sounds like a great idea. At least to me, but again I rarely understand what I'm doing ðŸ˜Š. Personally, I don't mind the limitations at all.

One nice thing with keyed services, is that when `Build` is called in the `ServiceCollection`, it verifies that all services can be created. So, if you ask for a (keyed) services that isnt't registrered, you will get an exception.

issue.title: [Feature] Add support for keyed services

repository.name: Polly
repository.description: Polly is a .NET resilience and transient-fault-handling library that allows developers to express policies such as Retry, Circuit Breaker, Timeout, Bulkhead Isolation, and Fallback in a fluent and thread-safe manner. From version 6.0.1, Polly targets .NET Standard 1.1 and 2.0+.

## The issue or feature being addressed

## Details on the issue fix or feature implementation

This PR adds support for keyed services into Polly.

## Confirm the following

body:
@pekspro 

I have created a PR that adds support for keyed services (#1881)
